statement:
**Theorem.** If the [*double series*]{} $$\begin{aligned}
\sum_{m=1}^\infty\sum_{n=1}^\infty a_{mn} =
  \sum_{n=1}^\infty a_{1n}+\sum_{n=1}^\infty a_{2n}+\sum_{n=1}^\infty a_{3n}
+\ldots\end{aligned}$$ converges and if it remains convergent when the
of the partial series are replaced with their absolute values, i.e. if
the series $$\begin{aligned}
\sum_{n=1}^\infty|a_{1n}|+\sum_{n=1}^\infty|a_{2n}|+\sum_{n=1}^\infty|a_{3n}|
+\ldots\end{aligned}$$ has a finite sum $M$, then the addition in (1)
can be performed in reverse , i.e.
$$\sum_{m=1}^\infty\sum_{n=1}^\infty a_{mn} = \sum_{n=1}^\infty\sum_{m=1}^\infty a_{mn} =
  \sum_{m=1}^\infty a_{m1}+\sum_{m=1}^\infty a_{m2}+\sum_{m=1}^\infty a_{m3}
+\ldots$$

[*Proof.*]{} The assumption on (2) implies that the sum of an arbitrary
finite amount of the numbers $|a_{mn}|$ is always $\leqq M$. This means
that (1) is absolutely convergent, and thus the order of summing is
insignificant.

**Note.** The series satisfying the assumptions of the theorem is often
denoted by $$\sum_{m,n=1}^\infty a_{mn}$$ and this may by interpreted to
an arbitrary summing . One can use e.g. the [*diagonal summing*]{}:
$$a_{11}+a_{12}+a_{21}+a_{13}+a_{22}+a_{31}+\ldots$$
